SnowDistribution: Wet snow at lower elevations with heavy drifting at higher altitudes. Winds 30 - 40 mph with stronger gusts. Poor visibility throughout the day above 800 metres.
Comment: Strong East-South-Easterly winds continuing for the next few days.
WeatherInfluences: Gale force East-South-Easterly winds. Snow above around 600 metres, heaviest overnight. Freezing level around 900 metres.
SnowStability: Fresh unstable windslab will develop through the period mainly on South-West through West to North aspects above 1000 metres with more localised deposits at lower elevations. Fragile cornices will develop above these aspects. Stability in the older snowpack will generally be good. The avalanche hazard will be Considerable.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Gale force East-South-Easterly winds. Rain gradually turned to snow down to 650 metres. The freezing level dropped to around 900 metres.
ObservedSnowStability: The existing snowpack has consolidated and stability is generally good. Fresh unstable windslab was developing through the day mainly on South-West through West to North aspects above 1000 metres. Fragile cornices were developing above these aspects. The avalanche hazard is Moderate.

SnowDistribution: Wet snow throughout. Diminishing snowpack, better above 700 metres. Cloud base was around 800 metres all day. Winds approx 40 - 50 mph making progress difficult and strenuous at times.
WeatherInfluences: Mostly dry during the forecast period with the chance of an isolated snow shower above 700 metres in the afternoon. Gale force East-South-East winds will ease slightly in the afternoon. The freezing level will be around 600 metres.
SnowStability: The snow pack will be generally well bonded and stable, becoming firm and icy above around 600 meters. Isolated and shallow deposits of soft fresh snow are likely above 1000 metres, these are expected to be insignificant and easily avoided. Decreasing threat of cornice collapse. The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: There were isolated showers during the morning accompanied by very strong to gale force South-Easterly winds. The freezing level went above the summits overnight and returned to around 900 metres during the day.
ObservedSnowStability: The snowpack stability is generally good. There is soft and thawing snow below 900 metres, firmer and more extensive cover above this altitude. The avalanche hazard is Low.

SnowDistribution: Snowpack became firmer after overnight thaw. Poor visibility above around 600 metres. Winds 30-40 mph.
Comment: Very heavy precipitation forecast Thursday night into Friday.
WeatherInfluences: Heavy snow above 550 metres during the night turning to rain below 850 metres by the end of the day. Storm force mainly Easterly winds overnight will become lighter during the day.
SnowStability: Unstable windslab will become deeper and more widespread over the forecast period. South-West through West to North aspects above 950 metres most affected, with more localised deposits at lower elevations. Fragile cornices will develop above these aspects. Wind exposed slopes will be scoured and stable. The avalanche hazard will be Considerable.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Rain at all levels initially gradually turned to snow above around 650 metres as the freezing level lowered. Gale force East-South-Easterly winds.
ObservedSnowStability: The existing snowpack is well bonded and stable. Localised deposits of fresh unstable windslab are developing in wind sheltered areas such as gully tops and coire rims. South-West through West to North aspects  above 950 metres are most affected. The avalanche hazard is Moderate.

SnowDistribution: No snow below 600m but with heavy drifting at higher altitudes.  Cloud base was at 700 metres all day.  Winds approx 40 - 50 mph making progress very difficult and strenuous.
Comment: The area is being affected by severe weather. High amounts of rain at lower levels with potentially 70 cm of snow forecast above 600 metres.
WeatherInfluences: Overnight the freezing level will be around 600 metres but rising to 800 metres during the day. Significant heavy snowfall throughout this period, heaviest overnight. Strong East-South-East gale force winds, easing very slightly during the day.
SnowStability: Deep weakly bonded windslab will develop on West to North aspects above 900 metres where avalanches will occur. Moderately to weakly bonded accumulations will also be present above 800 metres in wind sheltered locations on South-West, North-East and East aspects. Unstable cornices will also continue to develop. The avalanche hazard will be High.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Very wet with significant rainfall. This started to turn to snow above 500 metres, becoming drier with drifting around 900 metres. East-South-East winds, storm force for most of this period.
ObservedSnowStability: Heavy snowfall with drifting have formed unstable windslab mainly above 900 metres in wind sheltered locations on West to North aspects above 900 metres, South-West and North-East aspects have also been affected by cross-loading. Corrie rims, gully tops and steep, scarp slopes mostly affected. Unstable accumulations have also formed in other steep lee locations below this altitude.  The avalanche hazard is Considerable.

SnowDistribution: Winds approx 50 - 60 mph progress very difficult in exposed areas. Whiteout conditions with poor visibility above 900m.  Diminishing snowpack, good above 800 metres but deep and hard trail breaking in moist snow.
Comment: A lowering freezing level and persistent snow above 600m should improve snow cover but another wild day in prospect
WeatherInfluences: Precipitation will fall as persistent snowfall above 500m overnight and above 800m or so later in the day. Freezing level at 650m overnight rising to 850m by the end of the afternoon. Winds will be gale to storm force East-South-Easterly easing slightly later.
SnowStability: Fresh unstable windslab will build on South-West through West to Northerly aspects above 900m, becoming more widespread and deeper in wind sheltered places on W to NW facing slopes. Coire rims, back walls and gully tops most affected. On same aspects unstable cornices will build, threatening slopes below. The old moist snowpack will refreeze and stabilise.  The avalanche hazard will be Considerable.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: A damp day with a freezing level around summit levels for most of the day. Persistent showery rainfall below 800m sleet and snow above with snow becoming persistent on the tops later.  Winds gale to storm force East-South-Easterly.
ObservedSnowStability: Significantly diminished snow cover on all aspects. There is a moist and generally stable snowpack at lower elevations with the snowline around 700m. Above 950 metres on Westerly through North to North-Easterly aspects the snowpack is generally well bonded and stable with shallow new snow accumulations. Avalanche debris likely from cornice collapse noted a 800m on a NW aspect. The avalanche hazard is Low.

SnowDistribution: Wet soft snow at lower altitudes.  No visibility throughout the day above 800 metres. Winds approx 75 mph gusting over 100mph at summit levels.
Comment: Cooler conditions over the next 24 hours with continuous snowfall expected above 600 to 700m.
WeatherInfluences: Snowfall above 600 to 700 metres throughout the forecast period.  Storm force South-Easterly winds will ease strong to gale force and back East-South-Easterly during the afternoon. The freezing level will fluctuate between 700 and 800 metres.
SnowStability: Windslab will become increasingly more widespread over the forecast period with avalanches likely on steep wind sheltered West through North to North-East aspects above 800m. Crag aprons, gully tops and coire rims will be especially affected. Cross loading will affect South-West aspects during the afternoon, also localised instabilities will develop on steep banks below 800m and above 500m. On these aspects cornices will be unstable. The avalanche hazard will be Considerable.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Storm force South-Easterly winds with precipitation falling as snow above 900 metres, then to lower levels as it turned cooler through the afternoon. The midday freezing level was around 900 metres.
ObservedSnowStability: Unstable windslab has developed on West through North to North-East aspects, these accumulations are most widespread above 1000 metres, with the greatest instability in steep locations such as coire rims, gully exists and crag aprons. On these aspects cornices are fragile.  Better stability within localised accumulations below 1000 metres on steep banks and burn lines. The avalanche hazard is Considerable.
